hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with flatbread that's right not
only is this really flatbread it's also
really flatbread and what i mean by that
is unlike modern examples this is
nothing more than flour in water alright
so this is about as primitive a bread

ancient ancestor of any similar type
products you see today but anyway now
for the history lesson let's go ahead
and get started so we're gonna go ahead
and spoon some flour down onto our work
surface and I'm gonna use a combination
of whole wheat which is what this is
right here I kind of wanted to keep
going with that ancient bread theme so
I'm going to do a combination of whole
wheat along with some regular unbleached
all-purpose flour and then for just a
little bit of extra texture I'm also
gonna put a little bit of cornmeal and
other than a pinch of salt that's really
it for the dry ingredients so we'll give
that a little quick mix and then we're
gonna go ahead and make a well with our
spoon right in the middle which is going
to hold the next and last ingredient the
water so I'm gonna pour in some water
and we're gonna start mixing this stuff
up right on the counter oh yeah this
recipe predates the invention of the
stainless steel mixing bowl so we'll
take our spoon and we'll start slowly
mixing in some flour all I'm doing is
going around kind of poking the peeks
and slowly mix in a little bit of that
flour into the water and I first you're
gonna get like a thin batter and as you
continue drawing more and more flour
into the mixture it's obviously gonna
thicken up and I'm just gonna keep
working it with the spoon pulling in a
little more flour as I mix until we get
to the point where you're thinking to
yourself why am I still using this spoon
I should switch to my fingers so at this
point let's switch from metal to flesh
so I'm gonna give this kind of a little
kneading with my fingers and all we're
looking to do is introduce enough flour
so that we eventually get a very sticky
very soft dough that will just barely
pull away cleanly from the surface so
you see how we're using kind of a

our hand just rolling it around like
that picking up a little extra flour if
we need it until eventually we have
something that looks like this so you
can see it kind of wants to stick to my
hands it kind of wants to stick to the

not at that point your flatbread dough
is done now in a perfect world and by
perfect world that meaning you're not
filming this you'd wrap this up in

top for an hour or two to kind of mature
and let that flower kind of fully absorb
the liquid but I'm not I have things to
do so I'm gonna go ahead and cut this in

we're using the excess flour to flour to
the dough if we need flour the rolling
pin of course and the other really nice
thing about this technique is that you
could just make one flat bread or two

basically make this stuff to order it's
that quick so just a very simple very
easy technique which makes sense since
they were doing it like thousands of
years ago with no equipment but anyway
we're gonna roll that out to about an
eighth of an inch thick
using just enough flour so we can work
with it and speaking of rolling pin you

from the culinary store for just a

easy dough's make bad bread alright so

on a stone countertop or stainless steel
like I am here when you get down to near

of sticks to the surface that's actually

is the situation I have right here and

the way to placing this into a very hot

all my hot smooth rocks were in the

like to give that first side about a
minute
you'll notice that top surface changes

are little bubbles that are expanding in

help that process along I like to press

over again I like to give it the old
press oppressor and once it looks like
both sides are cooked and we have those
beautiful signature charm
and the blisters will simply remove it
from the pan and that's it your
flatbread is done and by the way if you
